definition:
Let $G$ be a locally compact group and $L^\infty(G)$ be the Banach space
of all essentially bounded functions $G \to {\mathbb{R}}$ with respect
to the Haar measure.

A linear functional on $L^\infty(G)$ is called a **mean** if it maps the
constant function $f(g) = 1$ to 1 and non-negative functions to
non-negative numbers.

Let $L_g$ be the left action of $g \in G$ on $f \in L^\infty(G)$,
i.e. $(L_g f)(h) = f(g^{-1}h)$. Then, a mean $\mu$ is said to be **left
invariant** if $\mu(L_g f) = \mu(f)$ for all $g \in G$ and
$f \in L^\infty(G)$. Similarly, **right invariant** if
$\mu(R_g f) = \mu(f)$, where $R_g$ is the right action
$(R_g f)(h) = f(hg)$.

A locally compact group $G$ is **amenable** if there is a left (or
right) invariant mean on $L^\infty(G)$.

All finite groups and all abelian groups are amenable. Compact groups
are amenable as the Haar measure is an (unique) invariant mean.

If a group contains a free (non-abelian) subgroup on two generators then
it is not amenable.
